steps.narration: September 1939: Germany invades Poland from the west, marking the start of WWII. The Soviet Union invades from the east.
June 1941: Operation Barbarossa begins - Germany launches the largest invasion in history against the Soviet Union with over 3 million troops.
August 1942-February 1943: The Battle of Stalingrad. One of the bloodiest battles in history becomes the turning point on the Eastern Front.
July 1943: The Battle of Kursk - the largest tank battle in history. After this defeat, Germany never regained the offensive on the Eastern Front.
April 1945: The Battle of Berlin. Soviet forces encircle and capture the German capital, leading to Germany's unconditional surrender.
December 7, 1941: Japan's surprise attack on Pearl Harbor brings the United States into the war. 'A date which will live in infamy.'
June 1942: The Battle of Midway. American forces sink four Japanese carriers, marking the turning point of the Pacific War.
August 1942-February 1943: Guadalcanal campaign. The first major Allied offensive marks the transition from defense to offense.
February-March 1945: Iwo Jima. American forces capture this strategic island after fierce fighting. The iconic flag-raising photograph becomes a symbol of the war.
April-June 1945: The Battle of Okinawa. The last and largest amphibious assault in the Pacific. Its ferocity influences the decision to use atomic weapons.
July 1943: Allied forces invade Sicily. This campaign leads to the downfall of Mussolini and Italy's eventual surrender.
June 6, 1944: D-Day. Over 156,000 Allied troops land on the beaches of Normandy in the largest amphibious invasion in history.
December 1944-January 1945: The Battle of the Bulge. Germany's last major offensive fails despite initial success in the Ardennes.
April-May 1945: The fall of Berlin marks the end of Nazi Germany. Hitler commits suicide, and Germany surrenders unconditionally.
October-November 1942: The Second Battle of El Alamein. British forces under Montgomery defeat Rommel's Afrika Korps, turning the tide in North Africa.
July 1943: With North Africa secured, the Allies use it as a springboard to invade Sicily and then mainland Europe.
